stories.text:
News from the 2021 Psychedelic Medicine Symposium VIRTUAL MEETING Sept.23, 4 PM PST:

I attended the SANA 2021 Symposium on Psychedelic Medicine, held from September 17-19th, addressing how psychedelics are changing psychology, psychiatry, corporate investment, research, and politics. In this FREE online meeting I’ll summarize 17 presentations covering:

• History of Psychedelics • Designing a New Psychedelic Psychotherapy • Psychedelic Use in Different Mental Disease States • The Gap Between Psychiatry and Psychotherapy • Preparing for the Journey: Setting Up for Treatment • Deeper Dive into Ketamine Treatment Models • Look to the Future: the Post-Legalization Landscape • Becoming a Certified Provider Attendance is free, to get the ZOOM URL, please register through eventbrite at:

https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/psychologys-psychedelic-renaissance-tickets-175787363737
stories.title: Psychology's Psychedelic Renaissance
DOJ Sues to Block Domestic Alliance Between American Airlines and JetBlue
Germany Wants to Force Gab to Censor, It’s Not Happening
Confessions of a Michelin Star Inspector
Why everybody’s hiring but nobody’s getting hired

stories.text: Was recently looking at political donations made by major tech companies and it was evident that most divert a large share of their lobbying spending on the Democratic party. I believe this is one such indicator of "liberal" leaning. Another is adoption of woke practices and ideas. It's pretty easy i think to point out liberal or progressive tech companies. Is there the equivalent for conservative? If not, what does that say about the tech sector?
stories.title: Ask HN: Is there such a thing as a conservative tech company?
Lyft built a brand on being the nice gig work app clad in pink; drivers disagree
